channel.title: Rsbot script, java interproject class question
channel.description:
so I created a seperate class in my project for walking, and i'm trying to reference a function from the walking class from my main class (the function makes the walking class do something with the char)
I'm getting an error in my java editor : "nonstatic (walking class) function cannot be referenced from a static context" from my main class. There is no static declaration anywhere, but I dont really know the dynamics of inter-class relations in java and this context

item.title: Rsbot script, java interproject class question
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

[quote=“BAsh, post:12, topic:214390”][quote]Personally I prefer 4 spaces rather than tabs. No I meant:

public Example[b]2 {[/b] public void exampleMethod[b]() {[/b] Example example = new Example(); example.nonStatic = 1; } }
[/quote]
^Fail[/quote]
^SPAMMING FAGGOT RETARD IDIOT

Read full topic

item.title: Rsbot script, java interproject class question
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“frank_, post:7, topic:214390”][quote author=Yz85Racer link=topic=282061.msg2296003#msg2296003 date=1214398495]
I don’t think I have ever seen someone use tabs as you do.
[/quote]randomly?[/quote]
Exactly.

[quote=“yakman, post:8, topic:214390”][quote author=Yz85Racer link=topic=282061.msg2296003#msg2296003 date=1214398495]
I don’t think I have ever seen someone use tabs as you do.
[/quote]

you’ve obviously never read any of my source files
i use tabs for indenting as well[/quote]
Personally I prefer 4 spaces rather than tabs. No I meant:

public Example[b]2 {[/b] public void exampleMethod[b]() {[/b] Example example = new Example(); example.nonStatic = 1; } }

item.source: Rsbot script, java interproject class question

item.title: Rsbot script, java interproject class question
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“surfer25, post:2, topic:214390”]i’ll give a quick example

public Example	{
	public int nonStatic = 0;
}

See there is no static variables?

We wouldn’t be able to do this

public Example2		{
	public void exampleMethod()	{
		Example.nonStatic = 1;// bad!!!
	}
}

now the fix

public Example2		{
	public void exampleMethod()	{
		Example example = new Example();
		example.nonStatic = 1;
	}
}

Its just a basic example. From there i think you can work it out[/quote]
I don’t think I have ever seen someone use tabs as you do.

Read full topic
item.source: Rsbot script, java interproject class question

item.title: Rsbot script, java interproject class question
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

There is an error in surfer25’s code. To make sense the method has to be static.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @supamagier supamagier
item.description:
@supamagier wrote:

You would be able to do

Example.nonStatic = 1;

if you make the int nonStatic… static.

item.title: Rsbot script, java interproject class question
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

haha wow, thanks. I cant believe I missed that, no wonder I d’d c++ class For some reason I was thinking I could create the object in an earlier function and have it become all encompassing… sigh

Read full topic
item.source: Rsbot script, java interproject class question

item.title: Rsbot script, java interproject class question
item.dc:creator: @surfer25 surfer25
item.description:
@surfer25 wrote:

i’ll give a quick example

public Example	{
	public int nonStatic = 0;
}

See there is no static variables?

We wouldn’t be able to do this

public Example2		{
	public void exampleMethod()	{
		Example.nonStatic = 1;// bad!!!
	}
}

now the fix

public Example2		{
	public void exampleMethod()	{
		Example example = new Example();
		example.nonStatic = 1;
	}
}

Its just a basic example. From there i think you can work it out

Read full topic
item.source: Rsbot script, java interproject class question
